qas.question: What become critical when a person is non-verbal?
What can be monitored as pain indicators?
Facial grimacing and guarding indicate what?
What type of social behavior might patients experiencing pain exhibit?
How can patients with dementia indicate discomfort exists?

plausible_answers.text: When a person is non-verbal and cannot self-report pain
patients who possess language but are incapable of expressing themselves effectively

qas.question: In what patients does a decrease in confusion signal pain?
What is an increased range of motion a sign of?
What can a change in baseline that deviates from the condition be a sign of?

context: <b5_0>When a person is non-verbal and cannot self-report pain<b5_0/>, <a0_0>observation<a0_0/> becomes critical, and <a1_0>specific behaviors<a1_0/> can be monitored as pain indicators. Behaviors such as facial grimacing and guarding indicate <a2_0>pain<a2_0/>, as well as an increase or decrease in vocalizations, changes in routine behavior patterns and mental status changes. Patients experiencing <b8_0>pain<b8_0/> may exhibit <a3_0>withdrawn<a3_0/> social behavior and possibly experience a decreased appetite and decreased nutritional intake. A change in condition that deviates from baseline such as moaning with movement or when manipulating a body part, and limited range of motion are also <b7_0>potential pain indicators<b7_0/>. In <b6_0>patients who possess language but are incapable of expressing themselves effectively<b6_0/>, such as those with dementia, an increase in confusion or display of aggressive behaviors or agitation may <a4_0>signal<a4_0/> that discomfort exists, and further assessment is necessary.
